review.title: A Large-Scale Multilingual Disambiguation of Glosses
review.abstract: Linking concepts and named entities to knowledge bases has become a crucial Natural Language Understanding task. In this respect, recent works have shown the key advantage of exploiting textual definitions in various Natural Language Processing applications. However, to date there are no reliable large-scale corpora of sense-annotated textual definitions available to the research community. In this paper we present a large-scale high-quality corpus of disambiguated glosses in multiple languages, comprising sense annotations of both concepts and named entities from a unified sense inventory. Our approach for the construction and disambiguation of the corpus builds upon the structure of a large multilingual semantic network and a state-of-the-art disambiguation system; first, we gather complementary information of equivalent definitions across different languages to provide context for disambiguation, and then we combine it with a semantic similarity-based refinement. As a result we obtain a multilingual corpus of textual definitions featuring over 38 million definitions in 263 languages, and we make it freely available at

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In addition to lexicography, where its use is of paramount importance, textual definitions derived from dictionaries or encyclopaedias are now generally a fact widely used in various areas of natural language processing of tasks and applications. sections.heading: 3. Methodology
sections.text: The core of our approach is to combine different languages and resources for high-quality ambiguity. Since many definitions are short and concise, the lack of meaningful context would negatively impact the performance of a Word Sense Disambiguation / Entity Linking system that targets individual definitions. To improve data quality prior to the disambiguation step, we highlight the definitions for a subset of languages: tokenization. We use the tokenization system from polyglot Project 6 for 165 languages. Part-of-Speech Tagging. We train the Stanford Tagger (Toutanova et al., 2003) for 30 languages using the available data from the Universal Dependencies Project7 (Nivre, 2015). Our disambigualization strategy is based on two steps: (1) all definitions are summarized, grouped by definition and by a multibiguous system using ambiguity (3.2).

sections.heading: 3.1. Context-rich Disambiguation
sections.text: Consider, for example, the following definition of castling in chess, as provided by WordNet: The exchange of the positions of the king and a kestrel. (1) The context in (1) is limited, and it may not be obvious to an automatic disambiguation system that the concept being defined refers to chess: an alternative definition of castling in which the chess game is explicitly mentioned would definitely support the disambiguation process. Following this idea, in the face of a BabelNet synset, we perform a process of context enrichment by collecting all definitions of this synset in every available language and resource and merging them into a single multilingual text. We use a graph-based approach to entity linking and word sense disambiguation, Babelfy8 (Moro et al., 2014) to disambiguate these definitions after preprocessing and context enrichment.

sections.heading: 3.2. Disambiguation Refinement
sections.text: Babelfy represents a series of ambiguous instances, i.e. mappings of text fragments to items in the BabelNet sense inventory, each associated with a trust (Babelfy Score henceforth). If Babelfy Score goes below 0.7, a common sense backoff strategy is used for that instance. Our goal is to correct or discard these ambiguous instances by using these ambiguous assimilation instances. First, for each ambiguous instance d we calculate a coherence scoreCd. Babelfy's coherence score is the number of semantic connections from d to the rest of ambiguous assimilation instances in the semantic graph (standardized): Cd = Disambiguated instances associated with d.

sections.heading: 5.1. Intrinsic evaluation
sections.text: First, we perform an intrinsic resource evaluation by manually evaluating the quality of the disambiguation using some randomly extracted definition samples. We rely on three human judges and evaluate samples of 100 items for three languages. We evaluated the disambiguity output before and after the refinement step and compared it to a baseline where each definition is unique to Babelfy. Table 4 reports on the evaluation of the three sample languages: English, Spanish and Italian. Although the disambiguation of context-free definitions improves only slightly in terms of the disambiguity of definitions in isolation, this improvement is consistent across all languages. Furthermore, our system significantly increases precision after the refinement step. Refinement decreases coverage by 35% for English and 43% for Spanish and Italian, but increases accuracy by almost 11% for English, 20% for Spanish and 13% for Italy.There is no easy way to estimate the first dictionary.

sections.heading: 5.2. Extrinsic evaluation
sections.text: The first experiment (Section 5.2.1.) evaluates our corpus before high-precision refinement and focuses on DEFIE (Delli Bovi et al., 2015), an Open Information Extraction (OIE) system that works with textual definitions. In its original implementation, DEFIE uses Babelfy to define definitions one-to-one before extracting relation instances. We modified this implementation and used the glosses that are ambiguous with our approach as input to the system, and compared the information extracted with the information gained through the initial implementation. Instead, the second experiment (Section 5.2.2.) evaluates our refined high-precision corpus and focuses on the semantic representations of NASARI (Section 3.2.). These representations were constructed based on the BabelNet network.

sections.heading: 5.2.1. Open Information Extraction
sections.text: In this experiment, we investigated the effects of our disambiguation approach on the definition corpus used as input for the DEFIE pipeline. The original OIE pipeline of the system takes as input an unstructured corpus of textual definitions, which is then pre-processed one-to-one to extract syntactic dependencies and distinct deteriorations. As highlighted in Section 3.1, the algorithm constructs a syntactic-semantic representation for each definition from which subject-bobobjective triples are derived.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we presented a large-scale, multilingual corpus of ambiguous glosses, ambiguity achieved by leveraging cross-resource and cross-language complementarities in textual definitions. By leveraging the structure of a far-reaching semantic network and inventory of meaning such as BabelNet, we obtained a completely ambiguous corpus of textual definitions from multiple sources and multiple languages, which, to the best of our knowledge, is the largest corpus of its kind available. In addition, we refined our sensory annotations by incorporating a module based on semantic similarity into our disambiguity inspiration pipeline to identify a substance of high-precision, ambiguous instances within the definitions. This refined version of the corpus has great potential in high-precision, low-coverage applications where a disambigusion error minimizes disamusion corptions.

In this paper we present a large-scale high-quality corpus of disambiguated glosses in multiple languages, comprising sense annotations of both concepts and named entities from a unified sense inventory. Our approach for the construction and disambiguation of the corpus builds upon the structure of a large multilingual semantic network and a state-of-the-art disambiguation system; first, we gather complementary information of equivalent definitions across different languages to provide context for disambiguation, and then we combine it with a semantic similarity-based refinement. As a result we obtain a multilingual corpus of textual definitions featuring over 38 million definitions in 263 languages, and we make it freely available at http://lcl.uniroma1.it/disambiguated-glosses. Experiments on Open Information Extraction and Sense Clustering show how two state-of-the-art approaches improve their performance by integrating our disambiguated corpus into their pipeline.
